title: MANSION  ---  House Call / Elizabeth Perkins:  Isolation Let  Her Dreams  Run Wild  ---  The co-star of 'The Moodys' on how life on a farm  and parental alcoholism led her to acting  ----  By Marc Myers
text:
The isolation came in waves. First, my parents divorced in 1963, when I was 3. Then my mother remarried when I was 5 and we all moved from Connecticut to a remote area near Halifax, Vt.

Soon, my two older sisters, Karen and Susan, left for boarding school. I was alone with my youngest stepbrother, Mark.

We looked out for each other. We had to. My parents were alcoholics. They weren't mean drunks. They just weren't present.

Our farmhouse and barn were built by my mother's father after he purchased 600 acres in the 1940s. We lived 4 1/2 miles from the main road and 2 miles from the nearest neighbor.

The property straddled Vermont and Massachusetts, with the state line running through our small guesthouse. We had chickens, a 2-acre vegetable garden, and a stream and beaver pond. My chores included mucking out the chicken coop and weeding.

In the summer, my stepbrother and I sold zucchini and tomatoes on the dirt road at the end of our quarter-mile driveway. Hours went by before a car appeared and stopped out of pity.

My mother, Jo, and stepfather, Bob, were completely ill-equipped to live in the country. I think we moved there so no one could see them drink. He had eight children but seven were older and out of the house. I was alone most of the time, except for my stepbrother, and my imagination grew. I invented entire scenarios in the woods and fields.

I learned later that my mother had started drinking heavily after my real father left. He worked at Playboy in the early '60s and bought into the bachelor culture.

As a child, I didn't see my real father much after he left. The bitterness remained with my mother for the rest of her life.

When I was 12, someone in school told me about the Arena Civic Theatre in nearby Greenfield, Mass. I auditioned for "Hansel and Gretel" and was cast as Hansel. From then on, acting was for me.

In school, I was troubled, probably because I wasn't well liked. I was a loner whose dreams intimidated other kids. I'd tell them, "One day I'm going to be a famous actress." They'd call me weird or that I needed my head examined.

My sisters were book smart and attended Northfield Mount Hermon, an elite boarding school, about a half-hour from our house. It wasn't difficult for me to get in. But I didn't want to go. My mother said if I refused, I should stick a pin in a map and we'd move there.

I decided to attend Mount Hermon. At the start of my senior year, I was kicked out for two offenses: I stole English muffins from the dining hall. And my friends and I made a phony phone call to the school infirmary.

By then, my mother's marriage had dissolved and she was living in North Carolina. But she wouldn't let me stay with her. My fallback was sleeping on my stepdad's sofa in Chicago.

I finished high school there and studied acting at the Goodman School of Drama, a conservatory. My acting teacher, Bella Itkin, was a huge inspiration. So was my classmate, Ann Dowd, an exceptional actress.

After college, I worked in Chicago for a couple of years. In 1982, I moved to New York with $500 and stayed with my sister, who was in finance.

After spotting an audition notice for the national tour of "Brighton Beach Memoirs," I landed the Nora Morton part and wound up in that role on Broadway in 1984.

Later in life, my mother became sober, went back to school, got her degree and became a social worker specializing in alcohol rehabilitation. She was one of my best friends. She died in 2016.

Today, I live with my husband, cinematographer Julio Macat, north of Los Angeles. We moved in 17 years ago. I love the house because of its fast access to the 405 Freeway.

A house is home, and home is about my husband, four kids and our dogs. Memories were always more important to me than things. Now I wish I owned our family farmhouse and land. Four years ago, I returned and tried to buy it. The owner wouldn't sell. I'm hoping one day he will.

-- As told to Marc Myers

---

Elizabeth Perkins, 60, is a stage, TV and film actress who has starred in "Big," "Weeds" (Showtime) and "Truth Be Told" (Apple TV+). She co-stars in Fox's comedy series "The Moodys."

---

ELIZABETHAN DRAMAS

What's "The Moodys" about? It's a comedy about a snippy married couple and their three eccentric kids.

Your role? Ann Moody, the mom.

Breakthrough film? "Big" (1988), as Tom Hanks's girlfriend.

Ever see your real dad again? Yes, we semi-resolved things later in life, thanks to my stepmother, Judy.
